aboutSection:
Kaufman County has experienced explosive growth over the past decade as families move east from Dallas seeking affordable land and a more rural quality of life. The city of Kaufman, as the county seat, sits at the center of this growth. While the town itself has some municipal sewer coverage, the sprawling residential development around it relies heavily on individual septic systems.

The dominant soil type across the Kaufman area is blackland clay, a dense, dark soil that defines the Texas Blackland Prairie running through the center of the state. From a septic perspective, blackland clay is among the most demanding soil types to work with. Its fine particle structure inhibits water movement, which means drain fields drain slowly and are prone to saturation during wet weather. The clay also exhibits significant shrink-swell behavior, expanding when it absorbs moisture and contracting when it dries. Over years, this cycle puts enormous mechanical stress on septic tanks, distribution boxes, and drain field piping.

Kaufman's position in the upper Trinity River watershed means some properties, particularly those near creeks feeding into the East Fork of the Trinity, deal with seasonally elevated water tables that compound the clay drainage problem. Properties in these lower-lying areas need systems designed and maintained with these conditions in mind.

Common problems we encounter in Kaufman County include structural damage to concrete tanks from clay movement, crushed or misaligned distribution lines, and premature drain field failure on properties where the system was installed without thorough soil analysis. Root intrusion from bois d'arc, hackberry, and pecan trees is persistent across the county. As more rural land gets subdivided for housing, we also see properties where the septic system location wasn't given adequate consideration relative to drainage patterns and soil variability.

faqs.question: How often should I pump my septic tank in Kaufman?
faqs.answer: Every two to three years is recommended for most Kaufman homes because the heavy blackland clay severely limits drain field efficiency. The clay forces your tank to retain more solids than it would in better-draining soil, so it fills up faster. Larger households should consider even more frequent pumping. We'll inspect your system and recommend the optimal schedule.
